reviewText: This is a well-written and well acted drama (four or five stars) about the grittier and more ambiguous aspects of legal and social services in modern-day Pittsburgh, PA.  Unfortunately, it has far more "downs" than "ups," and virtually all the characters are flawed, some very deeply.  If you are into these types of Dickensian, dark, storylines, then you will probably really like this series.  I have watched all of season one and about half of season two, but then I elected to stop.  It simply became too depressing, with almost everyone making almost always bad decisions and suffering the consequences.  Eventually there was no one left to root for.  I am no fan of the typical "everything always turns out fine" type of TV show -- unless that is the mood I'm in at the time -- but something needs to turn out OK eventually.
summary: A mixed bag of five star and four-star acting and writing but depressing characters and storylines

reviewText: The early episodes appealed the most as they sifted through the complexities of child welfare laws and practices. Seemed like more losers than winners however. The lead played by Simon Baker shifts between the self interested corporate law firm run by his smooth but hard nosed Republican father and a free legal clinic staffed by liberals. By staying a bit above the fray he remains a more interesting character than the rather stereotyped occupants of his two workplaces.  His good looks and soigné style seem credible in both settings though his character is noticeably awkward in the welfare trenches .

reviewText: I stumbled across this show on Netflix and watched all three seasons in less than a month; I wish that CBS had given this show more time.  Simon Baker is amazing as Nick, a character who is so emotionally-damaged and -immature; incredibly smart and capable in his professional life, yet a wreck and completely "unanchored" in his personal life.  Nick is a character we can all relate to, and Simon Baker's raw, edgy performance makes the viewer feel Nick's pain.  I think this show does a great job of showing Nick's struggle to "grow up" while also presenting the very real, and sometimes disturbing nature of the cases that appear in family court.  The rest of the cast is terrific as well, each of them struggling with their own demons and issues, but getting up every day and making the best of it. "The Guardian" is a show that is not always easy to watch - things don't always end up the way we'd hope them to - but it is definitely a show worth watching.  I love "The Mentalist" but this show is what has made me a true Simon Baker fan.

reviewText: I would give The Guardian 4.8 stars (only had a choice of 4 or 5).I loved this show when it first aired on CBS and subsequently bought the DVDs.  Simon Baker and Dabney Coleman are excellent as the strained attorney father and son team of Fallin & Fallin.  The premise of the drama is unique.Aussie Simon Baker does a fine job in the role the seemingly 'stiff and wooden' Nicholas Fallin.  The viewer soon comes to realize Nicholas is lacking something in his personality that makes him human.  He's a brilliant Richie-Rich corporate law shark, a recovering drug addict, and a felon ordered to serve community service in the most unlikely way:  As an advocate at Children's Legal Services of Pittsburgh where he is to represent the  best interests of children.  In the pilot, his law colleague, Jake Straka, says, "Leave it to you to find the profit in a non-profit."  Where as Nick lacks the ability to make a real human connection with adults, he is capable of relating to his child clients.The dual 'have vs. have-not' worlds of Nicholas Fallin are fascinating to watch and often at odds.  The supporting casts in both worlds are excellent. The writing, acting, and casting are also superb.  The chemistry among the cast is highly credible.The series had an arc with Nicholas Fallin which was actually concluded to the satisfaction of its viewers in the final episode, rare for shows of that time.  If you're a fan of Simon Baker, Dabney Coleman, Alan Rosenberg, legal shows, redemption, and/or complex dramatic relationships ... I highly recommend.

reviewText: I watched the series first time in 2013 on Netflix. It is an excellent show with superb writing and acting. It manages to have thrilling high drama stories without being a soap opera, like so many TV shows nowadays. The characters have many facets to their personalities, which give them depth and make them seem so real. The outcome of the stories is never predictable, so there is a real thrill in watching.  The stories are fascinating and edgy and taught me so much about the world of high powered wealthy corporate law firms and in contrast to that, the social work and legal advocate networks who deal with either poor or working class folks. It was a great concept for the show to have the main character working simultaneously in both worlds.
summary: FASCINATING and EDGY DRAMA with SUPERB WRITING and ACTING

reviewText: As Alvin tells him in the last episode of the third series, Nicholas Fallin is not as bad as he think he is, and probably he's not as bad as he wants to be.This is the story of a young corporate lawyer who works for his father during the day, and holds coke parties at night. Of course he gets busted and he gets sentenced to quite a huge amount of hours at children's legal service plus probation and a fine. THroughout the series we see him juggling his two jobs.This legal drama is not so much about legal stuff as it is about the personal growth of a very troubled thirsty-something man, who might have had everything his dad's money could buy, but healthy relationships with his family. He's clearly scared to death by his father's judgement, as much as he craves for his affection and approval. Emotionally, he's not older than most of his clients at LSP and sometimes he behaves like your perfect a..h..e, and your instinct would be of slapping his face.And yet, we gradually see that, behind his mask of arrogance and 'standoffishness' he is caring and shows concern for those around him. He often sounds as if he were on the verge of tears, and he goes the extra mile trying to help the children and adults he has been sentenced to serve. Even though he tries and adds minutes, if not hours, to his sentence log, he does not hesitate to even become foster carer for one of those children, or to go against social services, grandparents, and basically everyone else in order to grant the wishes of another one. All of this while he's constantly told off by basically everyone: his father, his boss at LSP, his boss at another firm, the group leader at the Al-An, his coworkers at LSP....Plots are very interesting, main actors are great, especially Dabney Coleman and Simon Baker, and the views of downtown Pittsburgh are just wonderful.Hope they'll put the other two series on DVD soon.
summary: He's not as bad as he think he is.

reviewText: 4.5 Stars...  Be warned, the character Simon Baker plays in this series is edgier than his character in The Mentalist and slightly more abrasive. However, that being said the first season of this legal drama was the strongest. At the time, Baker was billed as a new face with edge from Austrailia and the series got good critical reviews its first year.  Baker's seens with Dabney Coleman were amazing to watch as he struggled between goodwill legal work and the call of "the rich firm" run by his father. Alan Rosenberg was good though the character he played was less rich than his characters in other series (Cybil, L.A. Law, Civil Wars).  If you like Simon Baker in The Mentalist, and you don't expect him to always play the same exact character, you'll probably enjoy this first season and if like legal shows this series will also be enjoyable.  So what happened in the remaining seasons?  They retooled the premise to broaden their viewing audience and it watered down the show but this first season is definitely worth watching.  I'd also recommend catching the actor in the romantic dramedy: Something New, if you are a fan of his.

reviewText: When I graduated from law school, I came very close to practicing the type of family law the main character, Nick Fallon, has been sentenced to, so I may be a bit biased. With that having been said, I thought this was a terrific series.The most important ingredient of this series' success is the understated (and unfortunately, criminally underrated) performance of Simon Baker. Because of the manner in which he plays Nick Fallon,  you can see how the cumulative strain of:(1) Fallon being sentenced to thousands of hours of community service in most trying, heartbreaking area of family law --destitute, abandoned and defenseless children;(2) while struggling to stay productive at his tough-as-nails father's white-shoe mergers and acqusitions law firm and(3)remaining soberis (incrementally) tearing his character apart.I strongly recommend this series to anyone who is tired of the melodramatic and overwrought nature of other legal dramas. It was really thought-provoking and entertaining!
summary: Possibly One of the Best Legal Dramas Ever Aired

reviewText: The leading actor was doing his best.  I can't say why this story didn't really grab me, but it didn't.  I felt all along that there was a script somewhere in the background.  I was too aware that this was a television production and that these were actors playing their parts.  I didn't get involved in the story or feel for the characters.  I'm just a regular TV viewer out there wanting to be taken out of my world and into another if only for a while.  That didn't happen for me.  It seemed like a good theme, you know, kids and all, and I should have liked it more.  There was a time during the show I really didn't like that kid and I wondered if he did the murder instead of the Dad.  Maybe that will be the case in a future show, but that is a plot that's already been used several times.  I'm not interested enough to wait and see.  Probably lots of other people will like this show.  Don't let my pale indifference influence you, go watch it for yourself.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I became hooked on this series this summer (2009) while watching reruns on the Sleuth channel.  Excellent series - VERY well written, acted and produced.  I am also just discovering Simon Baker - an excellent actor in all his projects I've been able to find.  A natural in front of the camera; he's totally different in every one of his projects.ALL of the actors were amazing in this tough series - an edgy, bottled up, emotionally challenged Nick (Baker) dealing with his world of hurt when his mother dies and a sensitive boy is sent off to endure boarding schools and a cold Professional father (Dabney Coleman at his best) too tied up in a cold harsh business to help his hurting child.  It is fascinating to watch the emotionally fragile walls spin and tumble as characters grow, change and relationships continue to evolve as the black and white efficiency of law starts to turn more gray as the world changes for the characters through their exposure to distraught, fragile children and families.  They all start to discover how human and fragile they are.  It is SUCH a shame this series was cancelled - the final episode in year three was awesome...
summary: EXCELLENT TV drama series - so very underrated in so many ways

reviewText: In reel life there are few accidents, and so when slick young corporate attorney Nick Fallin is arrested on drug possession and sentenced to 1500 hours of community service as a child welfare advocate, the process of his own healing begins.Nick has been damaged not only by his wealthy parents' divorce and his mother's subsequent death, but because  his father [ Dabney Coleman] shunted him to boarding schools afterward yet now expects the world of him in terms of service to the law firm he founded.Though Nick is uncomfortable with any expression of emotion since he has built a fragile dam against his own pain, he soon becomes wrapped up in the world he encounters at Legal Services.What is so marvelous here is that there are few happy endings. Things are what they are--the family stories are sad and frightening, and though many of them are left open ended, the viewer knows that the patterns of dysfunction, poverty and abuse will be handed down generationally in most cases.The son and father interaction as well as the story lines involving corporate deals were interesting, though not as interesting as the children and their backstories. The one thing that takes away from the series is Nick's love interest, played by Wendy Monitz, who is perpetually confused about her attraction to Nick and marries a man she doesn't love instead --- highly contrived  in order to build sexual tension and begins to drag  after a while.Wonderful performances all around  [some of the guest stars playing corporate raiders and CFO's are as outstanding as they are disturbing] and particularly by regulars Kathleen Chafant as Laurie Stolt, a mature and dedicated social worker who has seen it all and yet still can make terrible errors in judgment; Rafael Sbarge as a callow corporate attorney [ the episode where he withdraws charges against a neglectful young mother he's been sleeping with is chilling]; and Farrah Fawcett who plays a winsome grandmother who still dresses inappropriately and becomes involved with Nick's father for a time.It's my understanding that the creator of the program based the scripts  on the experiences of his brother who works within the  child welfare system. Highly addictive.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you missed this series when it ran in the early to mid-2000's you may well find your favorite dramatic series is no longer on television or cable, but in this box set (and hopefully two forthcoming entries)."The Guardian" is not a "Murder She Wrote"-type series where there's a smoking gun and a criminal on the loose every episode.  Instead, the series is driven by Simon Baker's character who is many things--a lawyer by choice, a children's court appointed adovocate by sentence, an estranged son, and most of all a complex person with problems who has the tightest lips in the galaxy when it comes to voicing his own frustrations and concerns.As the episodes--and series--unfolds the viewer wonders how long Fallon (Baker's character) can keep it up.  He's heading for a breakdown and the suspense keeps one on the edge of his or her seat.  Questions also arise:  how did Nick Fallon get this way?  Why do he and his father work together, but don't seem to get along personally?  Is Fallon still abusing drugs?For fans of the series this release signifies a sigh of relief as the wait for this set has been long.  If sales are good then the world should be treated to the complete series and the saga of Nick Fallon will be lived and relived.  It is "just" a TV series, but it also reminds us that even adults need intervention from family and friends (and should accepted it when the offer is made).
summary: The Best Television Drama Comes to DVD

reviewText: After watching all three seasons of The Guardian, I have renewed faith in the quality of TV shows.  Simon Baker was EXCELLENT in the role of Nicolas Fallin.  He was negatively impacted by his childhood circumstances and symptoms of that fact is brilliantly leaked into every episode.  The supporting cast and guest actors, even the children, are great as well.  As a side note, there was never a hint that he has an Australian accent; I am always impressed when an actor can consistently hide their accent.  (I won't say anymore...don't want this to be a spoiler for The Guardian).  I have recommended this show many times to friends and family, and they have thanked me for it.  If you haven't seen it, check it out!
summary: The Guardian - All Seasons - Best Legal Drama Ever!!

reviewText: Simon Baker shines in this series as a lawyer required to complete community service legal work with children as a result of a drug conviction. Running along side this is his continuing work for the corporate legal firm headed by his father. Although  we don't see the light-hearted quips of  his later success as The Mentalist, we do see the insights and the ability to cut through to what matters. Strong story lines (not always with happy endings for the good guys) and good support actors make this an enthralling series - grittier than some of the court-room dramas without being bleak. The structure of the series allows the heart to be warmed by what he is able to achieve with children, while we can cheer his "stand up to the big guys" victories within the corporate world.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: I really like the way the story writers develop the characters in this series. reviewText: I have read some of the other reviews of all 3 seasons. At first I didn't agree with them but now that I've finished Season 3 I see what they mean. Season 1 was compact and well written with several story lines playing out each episode. By Season 3 the main characters', father and son Fallin, roles were diluted and changed in ways that didn't do their previous seasons justice. I could understand if they were softened a bit and perhaps even reconciled in their complicated antagonistic relationship. They were changed in ways that didn't seem to fit who they were. In one episode Burton had quadruple bypass surgery but the next episode he was completely 'healed' and back to work. Nick, we were led to believe had never stopped using drugs and alcohol and went into a major meltdown from which he was 'cured' in a 30-day 12 Step Program. Really?!! And yet it seemed to take forever for Lulu to show her pregnancy. Oh well! Got to watch Simon Baker!! One can only dream!!

reviewText: The Guardian is surprisingly well written, acted, with themes that are relevant today. I loved the authentic acting and felt sorry for the people in the stories who had problems, and glad that their problems were resolved by a caring lawyer. The lawyer featured in the series is unique in being concerned more with helping people than with simply getting rich at the expense of others. thus, this is a morally conscious series.Richard Shaw is the author of Teachers Matter, Wendy Sayvetz, Judy Collins and Joan Baez and Music Education in The Schools (Audible and Kindle)

reviewText: In Short: Nick Fallon, gorgeous, charismatic and smart corporate lawyer, is sentenced to community service by way of representing the children in legal services. He juggles his full time gig at his father's firm while completing his sentence. Nick gains an exceptional community of colleagues at the legal aid department and retains the interesting peers at the corporate organization. Watch as Nick compassionately fights for the best wishes of his underage clients and his now growing morals navigate him in the business world.Of all the law shows out there, "The Guardian" has become my favorite. The cases pull me in, and watching Nick develop as a person and as an attorney is addicting. His capacity for empathy is great and his determination to serve his clients is moving. Nick isn't completely soft though. He doesn't shy away from assertiveness when he deems it necessary.
summary: Corporate attorney serves the community in a charming, devoted role

reviewText: What a shame this show only went for 3 seasons...because this is a great show by any standards. The acting by all participants is first rate, it is well- written and fast-paced, and the stories are rich and emotionally challenging. I loved the way Simon Baker played his character...he makes a very convincing lawyer because he tries to remain emotionally detached and apply all his powers to achieving results for his clients, especially his children clients who find themselves in dire circumstances. This show is both touching and clever and it successfully achieves these things because Baker underplays his role. Just as a very good lawyer does his job dispassionately in the real world to retain his edge and remain effective, Baker gives us a very accurate portrayal of what it is to be a good lawyer in today's world. And his father is played by Dabney Coleman, another excellent actor! In fact, the show is littered with some really good actors in smaller roles too so there is quite a lot of light and shade offered here that make this show very realistic and a rewarding experience to view.

reviewText: I was captivated by this series. Nick Fallon (Simon Baker) kept us on the edge of our seats as he was unpredictable. While vulnerable & partly introverted, he was forced to deal with real life issues on the high-side of corporate law in his father's firm, while trying to gain acceptance among his peers & juggling his volunteer hours as a juvenile defender at the City's free law clinic. I loved the relationship between he & his father and he & his "friend," Lulu.  The show's contrasting mix of tough court decisions regarding the care & placement of at-risk-kids & their defective and/or dysfunctional parents/guardians was an awakening for me.  I was perplexed during the first 3-4 episodes as to why the show's title, "The Guardian," was named as such.  As the series progressed, the title started to make sense.  Nick was the type of "guy" that I, as a woman & mother, wanted to grab ahold of and rescue. He always found his way to "deal" with the problem cases, yet I was left with the constant impression that he was being traumatized within his soul.  Very good writing & production.
summary: Enlightening Law Case mix of corporate & domestic cases

reviewText: Nick Fallin.  Could there possibly be a more complicated character than this dude?  Psychologists must have loved watching this creation on television with his multifaceted personality.  He can be a tongue-tied child at one moment and a savvy attorney the next as he argues your case in front of the judge. He's intelligent, closed off, and barely communicates. To top it off, he's a former drug addict going through a very reluctant rehabilitation.The story begins when Nick, who was arrested for misdemeanor drug possession, is sentenced to 1,500 hours of community service.  He's the rich kid, who had everything.  His father is the big-shot attorney in Philadelphia who owns his own firm. He sent Nick off to boarding school at the age of 12 when his mother died.  His father is no better in expressing an ounce of honest emotion than Nicholas. The man can barely lift his head for two seconds to give his son eye contact, or if he does, he's pushing his bare palms over his nearly bald head.Even though Nick Fallin is a complicated mess that sometimes you want to shake by the shoulders and bring out of his shell, you have this motherly urge to hug him and let him know everything will be okay.  What I found intriguing is Simon Baker, who plays his role very well.  His facial expressions, his eye movements, the way he shrugs his shoulders, uses body language, or lifts the corner of his mouth up in his usual non-verbal responses tells you exactly what he's going through. When he smiles it flashes for a brief moment and then gets reigned back lest you think Nick could really be happy.  When you believe you have him figured out, he reacts differently and frustrates the hell out of you. On top of his inability to communicate and express his feelings, he is emotionally cut off from others. His greatest flaw is his denial that he doesn't have a problem, which he clearly does.His community service begins working with child legal services in representing children in court.  At first his arrogant pride puts him far above that kind of work. He's awkward to the point he's clearly challenged in dealing with emotional situations, especially those of kids. As the show progresses and the children make a difference in his life, you slowly learn that Nick Fallin is nothing more than a soft-hearted teddy bear deep down inside, with a rock-hard shell.  He just can't show it unless wild horses drag it out of him, or a particular woman.As the season progresses, the child community service loses its funding and becomes legal aid for adults.  Once again, he's challenged because he has to deal with adults as well as children. He falls for a woman in the office, but can't bring himself to tell her he cares until its too late.  His relationship with his father is tested to the core, and he once again dabbles in drugs for a short time to numb the pain he cannot express.All in all, after watching the first season, I'm going to tune in the others.  It's a great show.  Actually, a bit educational as well, especially learning what the legal guardian does for a child in court.  As far as Simon Baker, he's nice to look at.  In some of the shots, he looks very young.  He's supposed to be 32 in the series, but he reminds me at times of a 22 year old.  It's interesting to see how he's matured in his current work in The Mentalist.The other characters, as usual, have their own lives that suck you in, gut none are really as interesting as Nicholas.  It's worth the watch.  Of course, it only took me 12 years to finally get around to it, but what the heck.  Better late than never.SPOILER ALERT REGARDING ENDING OF SERIESThe series finale after Season 3 was a huge disappointment to me.  The writers could have done a wonderful job ending the series with a decent closure. Instead they focused upon a sub-plot regarding capital punishment that took up too much time from the lives of Nick, Lulu, his father, and Alvin.I wanted to yell at the writers of the show.  Okay, I get that all things come to an end, but not giving Nick and Lulu a happily ever-after relationship really disappointed me. You are led to believe their relationship is healed, and suddenly Lulu turns cold toward him when he's finally come to a place of responsibility and healing.Nick has bent over backwards to heal their relationship, care for their baby, purchase her a house, set up a trust fund, and go to counseling besides attending a rehab program and keeping clean.  Everything she asked for, he did.  The woman had too much control over his life and heart and gave him nothing in return but pain and rejection. I wanted to slap Lulu for not loving Nick, when it's clear that all the viewers fall in love with his repentant character.  I'm not sure if the writers knew that the season was not being renewed when it was written, but if they did....badly done...badly done.  I got the impression they really didn't care to end it on a high note or give the viewers what they hoped for all along.
summary: Nick Fallin - The Complicated Male Brain
